wikipedia_page.main: Anita Chapman MBE (born 3 July 1952 in Doncaster) is a British Paralympic archer who won medals at four Paralympics.

link_mentions.page: Archery at the 2004 Summer Paralympics – Women's team
Archery at the 1996 Summer Paralympics - Women's individual standing
response: The gold medal was won by Malgorzata Olejnik, wife of the men's champion Ryszard Olejnik. In the final she defeated Anita Chapman.

She concentrated on her archery skills and by 1996 she was considered an elite sportswoman and a contestant at the 1996 Summer Paralympics in Barcelona. She joined Anita Chapman and Rebecca Gale to gain a bronze medal for the UK in the women’s archery team open. At these games Chapman also won a silver medal. She had surgery in 1999 and she thought this might rule her out of competition, but at the 2000 Summer Paralympics she was again in Britain's team of three archers who competed for the women’s archery team open and this time they took the silver. Chapman gained a gold medal and Smith gained an individual silver in the women’s individual W1/W2 behind Paola Fantato of Italy. Four years later Smith won her fourth and last medal which was gold. She gained the gold in the women’s archery team open and again Anita Chapman was a team mate.
